corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection contains documentation from Omaha Tribal Powwows 1983-1986, including sound recordings and photographs created by American Folklife Center staff. Additional documentation from the 1983 powwow includes 35 pages of fieldnotes, 30 pages of handwritten tape recording logs, an 8-page program, and three posters. The collection also includes interviews with Omaha tribal members John Turner and Dennis Hastings.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Omaha Powwow Project collection was processed by Ann Hoog and Marcia K. Segal between 2016-2023.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: These related collections are at the American Folklife Center, Library of Congress:

p.ref: Alice C. Fletcher and Francis La Flesche collection of Omaha cylinder recordings (AFC 1948/123)
Rufus White and Maxine White interviewed by Gwen Meister, 1993 August 19 (AFC 1993/004)

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Omaha Powwow Project collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

altformavail.head: Online Content
altformavail.p:
The majority of the Omaha Powwow Project collection has been digitized. Selections are available on the Library of Congress website at
https://www.loc.gov/collections/omaha-indian-music/about-this-collection/
. Other collection materials have been digitized and available; please contact the Folklife Reading Room for more details.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Omaha Powwow Project Collection, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection contains documentation from Omaha Tribal Powwows 1983-1986, including sound recordings and photographs created by American Folklife Center staff. Additional documentation from the 1983 powwow includes 35 pages of fieldnotes, 30 pages of handwritten tape recording logs, an 8-page program, and three posters. The collection also includes interviews with Omaha tribal members John Turner and Dennis Hastings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Omaha Powwow Project collection is organized in seven series:

item.ref: Series 6. Interviews conducted by Alan Jabbour

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

geogname.part: Omaha Indian Reservation (Neb.)--Social life and customs--20th century.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Alan Jabbour, Carl Fleischhauer, Dorothy Sara Lee, Erika Brady, Dennis Hastings, Roger Welsch, John Carter, Mark Merrick, Sr., Joseph E. Harlan, Sr., Marvin F. Kivett, Bob Kerry, Elmer Blackbird, and others.

did.unittitle:
U Mon Hon Hethu'shka Society,
undated

scopecontent.p: Posters from the 1983 Powwow were relocated from Box-Folder 1/3.

did.physdesc: 23 photographs : film, negatives, black and white ; 35 mm
did.didnote: Photos from August 12 are described as "ruined." Frame 00 is included in the item count.

scopecontent.p: This roll is double exposed; the daylight stuff seems to have been made on the twelfth, and the night on the thirteenth. The day stuff (which is available from Kodachrome) includes Maria with her San Juan friend and the Robinson family getting ready by a car. The ruined night stuff includes Paul Brill giving out family tree charts, and Carl Fleischhauer carrying the Nagra to tape the San Juan folks. The only usable images are: 20-21, host drum at night, Tia Piah singers behind.

row.entry: Two arena directors with a fancy dancer with two things on the ground. I believe the two grounded items are held in the dancers hands while dancing. scopecontent.p: Tail section of Songs used to give honor to singers or drum groups.
An extra mike was moved by a woman singer, and later was placed in front of the women.
Discusses visit by Gov. Kerry's brother, assistant to the brother, then Bill Carrey (Carey?)
Then discussion of help from Sen. Exon [J. James Exon]
Cites previous help with getting electrical power
Bill Hopuer [sp?] and family [this is followed by an unclear note in Lee's handwriting: "no continue between #3 & 4"]

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:17) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: End of Buffalo Dance from San Juan Pueblo
Speaker: Betty Logdon [sp?], Nebraska Historical Society

San Juan Pueblo - Eagle Dance (continued on
SR05
. Lee notes: "switch mike - should be better on right")

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:11) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Rich and myself [sic - Dorothy Sara Lee] - speech to crowd
Announcement looking for dinner for the "nursing" home
"Clear the arena" announcement - Dorothy Lee and Band
Maria plays tapes, dancers dance to recordings

Loudspeaker with recording - left; Maria's voice - right. Continued on
SR06
.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:15) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Continued from
SR05
. Lee notes she may have lost 10-20 seconds of audio between reel changes.
Maria's show ends with Columbia cylinder of flute songs
Maria: on our plans for a record album
Dorothy presents tapes to tribal chairman
Next song (Drum #1 - speaker says something about princess)
Next song (Drum #1 - speaker names people - Pow-Wow Princess Special)
Dance led by princess and older women

did.unittitle:
Tape 7 [not marked in audio log],
August 13, 1983
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:21) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: [?] giveaway by princess (at this point the tape was shut off for about half an hour, and turned on again for the announcements)
Next song, honoring someone (for Louis Dick [Louis Dick, Sr.]); lead dancer may have been brother Albert Dick [Albert Dick, Sr.]
Mr. Dick (is it Louis?) makes speech (of thanks?) in Omaha [language] (at this point there were more small giveaways and remarks, etc., which were not recorded)
Recording restarted in time for the flag lowering song (Lee notes that "the action wiggled the flagpole; some electrical fizzing on our wire")
Flag lowering followed by a song (the song title is noted on the tape)
Announcements - supper, etc. (the recording is "cut for supper)

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:23) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Grand Entry (continued from
SR07
; tail end; about 30 seconds)

Tail Dancers - four Traditional War Dance Songs ("Wakonda," the second song of four, is on cylinder, and was played earlier in the afternoon at the presentation. This set of four songs are original Helushka.)
Song for Head Dancer - "Whipman (for David Blackbird)
Introduction of Singers; Princess; Arena Directors; Water Boys, Pow-wow Committee
"Honey Creek Singers" - Sneak Up Dance (a little off-mike)

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:30:36) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Tiny Tots Shawl Contest (seven contestants; singers will sing two times through)
Song #1 - warm-up by singers off to side
Song #2 - contest song for Girls shawl
Junior Girls' Shawl Contest (fourteen contestants (split in half); Tia songs off to side)

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:29:08) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Girls' Fancy (continued from
SR09
; this contest had to be judged over again, as there were ties, and some confusion about the number of judges)
Tiny Tots Male Fancy (one contestant - "automatic champion" - E.J. Snowball?)
Junior Boys Fancy (7-12 years; seven contestants)

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:32:15) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Speech by Alfred Gilpin, Omaha (about Paul Brill, who helped Omahas on tribal enrollment; Honor Speech for Paul Brill; made family trees for Omaha families)
Presentation of Family Trees (scroll with ribbons tied around)
Another general dance song by Honey Creek
Second general dance by Tia Piah drum group

scopecontent.p: End of third general dance - host drum
Announcement for Pueblo Butterfly dance (explanation of songs)
Check for phasing (else placement of mikes); Carl carried mics around with singers. Praise singer puts down drum.
Something lost in here while rehooking up to other Nagra
